question: In patients undergoing femoropopliteal vein bypass, does elevated plasma fibrinogen (hyperfibrinogenemia) reduce the risk of graft thrombosis compared with normal fibrinogen levels? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: Patency was significantly higher by life table analysis in patients with a plasma fibrinogen concentration below the median than in those with a concentration above (90% v 57%, p less than 0.0002).
content.source_2: In multivariable Cox regression adjusted for smoking exposure, elevated plasma fibrinogen was independently associated with a lower hazard of graft thrombosis, and patients with patent grafts exhibited higher fibrinogen alongside favorable apolipoprotein profiles (p<0.01).
content.source_3: CONCLUSIONS Plasma fibrinogen concentration was the most important variable predicting graft occlusion, followed by smoking markers.
content.source_4: Clinical management prioritized serum cholesterol over coagulation factors; attempts to reduce fibrinogen did not enhance patency, whereas persistent hyperfibrinogenemia was linked to fewer occlusions during longitudinal follow-up.
